required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Outcomes After Sacrocolpopexy With and Without Burch to Prevent Stress Urinary Incontinence in 3rd and 4th Degree Apical Uterine Prolapse
clinical_study.official_title: Outcomes After Sacrocolpopexy With and Without Burch to Prevent Stress Urinary Incontinence in 3rd and 4th Degree Apical Uterine Prolapse. Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Urinary incontinence will develop after prolapse repair in approximately one quarter of patients with advanced pelvic organ prolapse who remain continent despite significant loss of anterior vaginal and pelvic organ support. Many women with advanced pelvic organ prolapse who choose to undergo surgical management also choose to undergo continence surgery in order to prevent new onset urinary incontinence.

primary_outcome.measure: the percentage of stress incontinence post operative

intervention.description: polyglactin suture was passed through the Cooper's ligament bilaterally with the guidance of the valve

By careful dissection (to avoid large veins in this region), expose the back of the pubic bone and the lateral aspects of the urethra. The right-handed operator double gloves, and places the left hand in the vagina. With fingers on either side of the catheter in the vagina, define the urethrovesical junction (at the balloon). Place three Ethibond J-shaped sutures on either side of the urethrovesical junction.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Women with 3rd and 4th degree Apical prolapse
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with previous failed surgical intervention
- Patients with medical disorders that may interfere with surgical interventions .
- Patients with apical prolapsed complaining of stress urinary incontinence
